Maneuvering might not be possible since there is no resistance or point of contact to introduce external unbalancing force, its like trying to displace a car while you are still inside it. But as far as introducing rotation in the body, turning our neck and then our back and then legs in that order is possible even in a 0 gravity non resistance free fall environment, since the axis of rotations for each of those parts are different and independent of one another and does not need any external unbalancing force. Let me know if you have a better/correct answer.

Yup, I'd say pretty much all balance on the unicycle is instinctive.
I have been riding unicycles for the past 11 years. My senior year, I rode to school every day on a giraffe unicycle. Part of the dirt road (I was in Mali) on the way to school was steeply angled, and I noticed that I "waxed on" on the way to school and "waxed off" on the way back, as if I was greasing an invisible frying pan.
I tried simply leaning instead but found I had to lean so far it was more efficient to use my hands.

to elaborate:  I think the amount of friction on your tire, and the amount of rotation you can get with a tiny (maybe subconscious) lean totally dwarfs any effect of swinging your arms around.

As an example: Your office chair almost certainly has less friction than your rubber tire on pavement.  If the arm wheeling was responsible for your turn, you should be able to make comparable turns faster by wheeling your arms in your office chair than you can on your unicycle.  Try it. ;)

yeah, I understand how the office chair trick works.  I'm just suggesting that wheeling your arms in a "small horizontally circular" fashion is going to do very little as a method of turning.  As with so many things in unicycling, you're probably doing a lot of things without realizing you're doing it.  It tends to be mostly instinctive, and I'm often surprised when I realize that I've been instinctively doing something for years without realizing it, or considering how it works.

I usually do it to augment the torso turning. If you sit in a revolving office chair you'll find it does little to simply rotate your torso. If you rotate your torso with your arms on the inside and on the way back, you extend your arms (even slightly) it magnifies the effect. Leaning does the same.
The "arm waving" is usually in response to riding a giraffe uni perpendicular to the angle of terrain (when it feels like it's constantly pulling to one side) and is preferable to leaning way over.

Unless you ride very differently than me or any of the unicyclists I know, the arm waving is making a fairly minor contribution at best.  When I need to make sudden pivots when my wheel isn't spinning I'll twist my torso first, and then extend my arms and pivot my hips to follow in one quick motion.
This is somewhat similar to what the question is asking about, but I am also using friction to my benefit by bouncing slightly to unload the tire while I turn.

Let me try... Start straight as an I and go into a T shape  with your arms (making your arms an anchor), twist your lower body, and while keeping your body twisted go back into an I shape and once you are in the I shape, twist your lower/upper body back and you start spinning when you want to stop extend your arms back into a T shape and voila. I ride a unicycle. People like to ask me how I stay up, or go downhill, but to me the most interesting question is how do I turn. Yes, I could simply lean to the left or right, but sometimes that's not an option, especially when I'm navigating a complicated route.
What I do is make small horizontally circular movements with my arms. At the furthest point, the motion of my arm affects me more greatly than at the point closest to my body. This causes me to turn.
Dunno if it'd work in space though.

Yes, it's possible. Let's try it on rotable chair first (two dimensional example with low resistance): 
1. extend your arm
2. rotate it left
3. retract your arm
4. rotate it right
5. repeat from step 1
Conservation of rotating momentum will rotate your body without breaking any science rule.

The same principle works in space. You just have to be more careful not to rotate in undesirable way.

The cat's ability to rotate depends on the difference in the angular inertial of the front and rear halves of it's body, as Destin explained in the first video. Because of this the cat should be able to do this maneuver in a (hypothetical) gravity free environment. In reality the cat would be highly disoriented and probably couldn't perform due to that, but physically they should be able to do it.
As for a human it's possible? Not sure we could get the contortions right but the physics works.

I'd say Yes, you can spin in space. If you turn the top half of your body then quickly turn it in the opposite direction swinging your arms out as you do so then the acting momentum of your push should spin you around. However I don't think you could stop without an outside force being applied as the lack of friction force from gravity  would not be applied to slow or even stop your rotation. Let me know what you think, and I'm the one who looks up to YOU Destin! Thanks!

To accomplish this maneuver the cat uses the unequal force of gravity to start his spin. Although gravity is still at play in the freefall of the ISS, that force is balanced by centrifugal force, so there is no unequal force at play. There IS other matter to push against in the space station, including air, but flailing at air is a very inefficient way to accomplish a spin. The videos referenced by Dobie Tanpaw show how difficult it is for cats to do this in a zero G environment.
